Label: Main finding on traditional social values

Label: Main finding on partisanship
Evidence: At the regional level, for each model the winner and loser dummy variables have significant impacts on institutional trust, positive for the case of the winner variable and negative for the loser variable

Label: Main finding on social capital
Evidence: For both social trust and organizational membership, there is a much greater level of variation in significance from model to model and from country to country, suggesting the institutional approach is more consistent than the cultural approach

Label: English
Evidence: Entire article written in English

Label: Empirical
Evidence: We make use of the data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014), in which a representative sample of voters has been surveyed in the context of both the 2009 and the 2014 Belgian elections.

Label: Both
Evidence: The Belgian context consists of two separate party systems; one of Dutch-language parties and one of French-language parties. The analysis covers both regional and federal levels of parliament.

Label: Yes
Evidence: The relation between distrust and protest voting reinforces one another, leading to a potential spiral of distrust. Low levels of political trust are associated with a preference for protest parties.

Label: Main research question stated
Evidence: we investigate the dynamic relation between political trust and voting behaviour by means of a panel design. This allows studying how the trust level of protest voters evolves following their vote decision.

Label: Voting in parliamentary elections (when explicitly linked to parliamentary representation)
Evidence: Additionally, we point out that decreasing levels of trust significantly increase the probability of voting for a protest party

Label: Trust/confidence in parliament
Evidence: Low levels of political trust are associated with a preference for a protest party. As a measure for political trust, we use respondents' indicated level of trust in the following institutions; political parties, the regional government, the regional parliament, the federal government, the federal parliament and politicians.

Label: Unclear
Evidence: The authors operationalize political trust through six survey items (trust in political parties, regional government, regional parliament, federal government, federal parliament, politicians) on a 0-10 scale but do not provide an explicit conceptual definition of what political trust means theoretically.

Label: Comparative (two or more cases)
Evidence: We examine voting in the two party systems separately. For the Flemish region... For the French language parties...

Label: Case-study (single case)
Evidence: In this paper, we investigate the dynamic relation between political trust and voting behaviour by means of a panel design. This allows studying how the trust level of protest voters evolves following their vote decision. We make use of the data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014)
We rely on data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014), in which a representative sample of voters has been surveyed in the context of both the 2009 and the 2014 Belgian elections.

Label: Belgium
Evidence: We investigate this relation in Belgium, as this country offers an ideal setting, both for the study of political trust as for the study on protest voting.

Label: Surveys
Evidence: The 2009 part of the panel survey consisted of three survey waves... 1,698 respondents took part in this post-electoral survey wave and were interviewed by phone... these respondents were contacted again to participate in the 2014 part of the panel study. A total of 792 respondents... sent back a paper questionnaire

Label: Primary
Evidence: We rely on data from the Belgian Election Panel (2009-2014), a representative survey of voters in the two main regions of Belgium (Flanders and Wallonia), based on a sample from the National Register of the citizens of Belgium.

Label: Quantitative (descriptive, bivariate, statistical aggregation)
Evidence: The mean values for political trust in Table 1 additionally point out a decline in political trust between 2009 and 2014. We first descriptively assess changes in levels of political trust between 2009 and 2014 for the electorates of different parties.

Label: Quantitative (statistical modelling, regression analysis)
Evidence: we present the results of a series of multinomial logistic regression models... We perform a multivariate analysis explaining the impact of the vote choice in 2009 on levels of political trust in 2014, while controlling for the 2009 level of political trust. For doing so, we run an OLS regression

Label: Summary of main findings
Evidence: Our findings hint at a 'spiral of distrust'. Low levels of trust as well as decreasing levels of political trust increase the probability of voting for a protest party. Having chosen such a party subsequently acts to decrease one's level of trust in politics even further. The result is a spiral of distrust, where distrust and protest voting enforce each other.

Label: Moulds
Evidence: DR SARAH MOULDS

Label: Complete bibliographic citation
Evidence: Sarah Moulds, 'A Toolkit for Evaluating the Effectiveness of Parliamentary Public Engagement', University of South Australia Law Review, Vol 5

Label: Year when the publication was published
Evidence: Not explicitly stated in article text

Label: Article
Evidence: Published in University of South Australia Law Review, Vol 5

Label: English
Evidence: Article is written in English

Label: Theoretical
Evidence: Article aims to 'describe the key ingredients for effective evaluation of public engagement by parliaments and share the toolkit developed by the IPEN workshops' - it develops frameworks and tools without conducting original empirical data collection and analysis

Label: Both National and Sub-national
Evidence: Article discusses 'Over the past decade, Westminster-inspired parliaments in Australia, New Zealand ('NZ'), Ireland, and the United Kingdom ('UK') have been experimenting with new ways of connecting' and references 'European Parliament', 'Scottish Parliament', and 'local councils and governments'

Label: Partially
Evidence: Article focuses primarily on evaluation methodologies and public engagement strategies rather than attitudes themselves, though it references attitudes like trust: 'enhancing the quality and diversity of engagement between the public and Australian parliaments is essential to preserving trust in democratic institutions'

Label: As stated by the authors
Evidence: Article states aims rather than formal research questions: 'this article aims to describe the key ingredients for effective evaluation of public engagement by parliaments and share the toolkit developed by the IPEN workshops'

Label: Petitioning
Evidence: E-petitions section: 'Petitioning the Parliament is a long-established, direct, and lineal form of public engagement initiated by a citizen or group who asks the a parliament to take specific policy or legislative action' and 'since 2016, the Australian Parliament has accepted 'e-petitions''

Label: Participation in formal consultations/hearings
Evidence: 'Parliamentary committees have long been the site of engagement between citizens and members of parliament, particularly committees with broad powers of inquiry' and discussion of 'citizens' juries' and 'mini publics' as formal consultation mechanisms

Label: Parliamentary visits/events
Evidence: Discussion of 'open days, tours, educational activities' and references to 'Parliament Unpacked Program'

Label: Social media engagement with parliament
Evidence: References to 'digital communication tools (including websites, social media, and video conference technology)' and 'a young person decides to respond to a social media post shared by a parliamentary committee'

Label: Consumption of parliamentary information
Evidence: References to 'watching debates, reading official sites/reports' and 'legislation tracking apps'

Label: Trust/confidence in parliament
Evidence: 'enhancing the quality and diversity of engagement between the public and Australian parliaments is essential to preserving trust in democratic institutions' and discussion of 'decline in public trust for parliaments'

Label: Perceived legitimacy of parliament
Evidence: 'Since parliaments derive their legitimacy from the people, public disenchantment threatens their authority' and discussion of 'legitimacy' as a factor in engagement evaluation

Label: Perceptions of responsiveness
Evidence: Discussion of 'Responsive: Focus on meeting public expectations by listening to community feedback and continually improving' and references to parliament 'listening to the community'

Label: Perceptions of accessibility/usability
Evidence: Multiple references to accessibility including 'Inclusive: Make inclusion a priority so that parliament is accessible to all community members' and 'test accessibility having regard to profile of publics/groups'

Label: Public Engagement
Evidence: Public engagement is about 'empowering people in relation to their surroundings to make a difference to the decisions and actions that affect their lives' and encompasses 'public communication; public consultation; and public participation'

Label: Deliberation
Evidence: Deliberation is 'a process in which citizens not only participate, but also engage with parliamentarians to lead or significantly shape an activity that contributes to a parliamentary decision' requiring that 'decision-makers have access to accurate and relevant information, consider a diversity of voices and positions, reflect on information received, and reach conclusions based on evidence'

Label: Representative Democracy
Evidence: Article states 'Fostering a strong and meaningful connection between people and their elected representatives is the central work of any functioning democracy'

Label: Not Applicable
Evidence: Article is theoretical/framework paper, not empirical study

Label: Time period analyzed
Evidence: No specific time period is analyzed; article references historical context dating back decades and discusses current practices without analyzing a defined timeframe

Label: Australia; United Kingdom; New Zealand; Scotland; Spain; Brazil; Germany; European Parliament
Evidence: Article discusses 'Australian parliaments', 'Westminster-inspired parliaments in Australia, New Zealand ('NZ'), Ireland, and the United Kingdom ('UK')', 'Scottish Parliament', 'European Parliament', and provides examples from 'Brazil', 'Spain', and 'Germany'

Label: Secondary data extraction
Evidence: Article synthesizes existing literature and frameworks: 'Drawing upon insights shared during a series of international workshops on public engagement by the International Parliamentary Engagement Network ('IPEN')' and integrates findings from IPU Report and case studies

Label: Secondary
Evidence: Article draws on 'international workshops', existing case studies, and published reports such as 'the Global Parliamentary Report 2022' rather than conducting primary data collection

Label: Qualitative (content analysis, discourse analysis, ethnographic methods, interviews, qualitative synthesis)
Evidence: Article synthesizes qualitative case studies and frameworks: 'While there are some promising case studies of individual experiences with innovative parliamentary public engagement strategies, there is currently a lack of systematic analysis'

Label: Summary of main findings
Evidence: Key findings include: (1) public engagement requires inclusivity, diversity, empowerment, flexibility, meaningfulness, and transparency; (2) deliberative approaches improve policy outcomes and legitimacy; (3) New Zealand's engagement strategy improved parliament reputation (53.9 to 61.2 points) and voting commitment (18% to 32%); (4) evaluation frameworks must assess legislative impact, public impact, and hidden impact; (5) Australian parliaments must reach beyond 'usual suspects' to engage marginalized communities including First Nations peoples

Label: Additional comments
Evidence: This is a toolkit and framework paper that synthesizes international best practices for evaluating parliamentary public engagement. While theoretical in nature, it incorporates findings from empirical studies conducted by other organizations (NZ Parliament survey, Climate Assembly UK evaluation). The article provides practical guidance rather than reporting original research.

Evidence: Not reported in article

Evidence: Cho

Label: Complete bibliographic citation
Evidence: Wonbin Cho. 2012. Accountability or Representation? How Electoral Systems Promote Public Trust in African Legislatures. Governance, Vol. 25, No. 4, pp. 617–637

Label: Year when the publication was published (numeric)
Evidence: Governance: An International Journal of Policy, Administration, and Institutions, Vol. 25, No. 4, October 2012

Label: Article
Evidence: Published in Governance journal, Vol. 25, No. 4, October 2012 (pp. 617–637)

Label: English
Evidence: Entire article written in English

Label: Empirical
Evidence: This article mainly draws upon individual-level survey data collected by the Afrobarometer in 16 sub-Saharan Africa countries between March 2005 and March 2006

Label: National
Evidence: The dependent variable in this article is the level of confidence that people place in the legislature

Label: Yes
Evidence: It traces confidence in legislative institutions to whether a citizen perceives competitive elections to produce accountability and/or representation

Label: Research question explicitly stated
Evidence: How do ordinary citizens build their confidence in the legislature, particularly in Africa's emerging democracies?

Label: Research question explicitly stated
Evidence: Whether and how multiparty elections work as instruments of democracy in emerging African democracies

Label: None
Evidence: The study examines perceptions and attitudes toward elections and parliament, not actual citizen behavioral engagement such as petitioning, contacting MPs, or voting participation

Label: Trust/confidence in parliament
Evidence: The dependent variable in this article is the level of confidence that people place in the legislature. Respondents were asked: How much do you trust the parliament?

Label: Definition of institutional trust provided
Evidence: At a basic level, public trust in a given institution is an evaluative orientation focused on how well the institution is operating according to some normative expectation

Label: Definition of trust elaborated
Evidence: Citizens put their trust in political institutions based on their evaluations of the performance of those institutions

Label: Comparative (two or more cases)
Evidence: This article mainly draws upon individual-level survey data collected by the Afrobarometer in 16 sub-Saharan Africa countries between March 2005 and March 2006

Label: Time period analyzed: 2005-2006
Evidence: The data are derived from national probability samples collected between March 2005 and March 2006

Label: Benin; Botswana; Cape Verde; Ghana; Kenya; Lesotho; Madagascar; Malawi; Mali; Mozambique; Namibia; Nigeria; Senegal; South Africa; Uganda; Zambia
Evidence: Benin, Botswana, Cape Verde, Ghana, Kenya, Lesotho, Madagascar, Malawi, Mali, Mozambique, Namibia, Nigeria, Senegal, South Africa, Uganda, and Zambia

Label: Surveys
Evidence: This article mainly draws upon individual-level survey data collected by the Afrobarometer in 16 sub-Saharan Africa countries

Label: Secondary
Evidence: The data are derived from national probability samples collected by the Afrobarometer, which the author analyzed

Label: Quantitative (statistical modelling, regression analysis)
Evidence: Due to the multilevel structure of data set, I estimate my model using multilevel analysis

Label: Main finding on representation priority
Evidence: When ordinary Africans build their confidence in the legislature, I found, they focus more on whether elections facilitate the scope of representation of all the factions of society than on whether they can directly reward or punish their representative through regular elections

Label: Main finding on electoral systems
Evidence: PR systems work better for boosting the positive effects of MPs' political representation on public trust in the legislature than majoritarian systems do

Label: Finding on accountability mechanism
Evidence: I found no evidence indicating that the effect of popular perceptions about their ability to replace electoral officials on their confidence in the legislature is greater in countries with majoritarian electoral systems than in countries with PR systems
